content.raw: Just want to get a quick note in - this seems to make it really long; potentially infinite.  I'm trying to probe this further, but I had a world where I had 'beamed' to another checkpoint, and this detection never triggered.  I hadn't thought of this commit, so I didn't give it hours and hours, and I will try to probe this a bit further.  But if you haven't frozen 0.6, you might wait a hair...
content.html: Just want to get a quick note in - this seems to make it really long; potentially infinite. I'm trying to probe this further, but I had a world where I had 'beamed' to another checkpoint, and this detection never triggered. I hadn't thought of this commit, so I didn't give it hours and hours, and I will try to probe this a bit further. But if you haven't frozen 0.6, you might wait a hair...

content.raw: Well, perhaps a false alarm.  I cannot now reproduce the faulty behavior.  I may simply have not waited long enough. (I had one case where it was 8 simulated seconds, which at 0.1 is a long time...)
content.html: Well, perhaps a false alarm. I cannot now reproduce the faulty behavior. I may simply have not waited long enough. (I had one case where it was 8 simulated seconds, which at 0.1 is a long time...)

content.raw: Phew, glad to hear! Yeah there's a balance between time and stability...
content.html: Phew, glad to hear! Yeah there's a balance between time and stability...

content.raw:
In the interest of historical records, I think I understand what confused me.  That is, if I do this sequence:  start a random world, wait until I'm clearly harnessed, and then command to start task 2, checkpoint 3, the robot correctly moves.

It *also* correctly sets a harness status right away, but there are no corresponding messages on the terminal.  So if you look at the terminal output, you think, 'hey, I can send messages', and if you send walking commands while in the harness, then that seems to bollix things up such that the harness never detects the lowering, and you're stuck.
content.html:
In the interest of historical records, I think I understand what confused me. That is, if I do this sequence: start a random world, wait until I'm clearly harnessed, and then command to start task 2, checkpoint 3, the robot correctly moves.

It also correctly sets a harness status right away, but there are no corresponding messages on the terminal. So if you look at the terminal output, you think, 'hey, I can send messages', and if you send walking commands while in the harness, then that seems to bollix things up such that the harness never detects the lowering, and you're stuck.

content.raw: I instrumented this with the 2ms branch, and found that the value gets *up* to 499, but doesn't sustainably go over 500; it eventually settles at around 465.    I'd suggest 450 as a better value than 500.
content.html: I instrumented this with the 2ms branch, and found that the value gets up to 499, but doesn't sustainably go over 500; it eventually settles at around 465. I'd suggest 450 as a better value than 500.
